title: Have you ever enjoyed a sequel more than the original movie? Why? - Quora

response.answer_text: I grew up in the 70s and 80s and back then, it was possible for sequels to have much better graphics and cinematography than the originals, especially if there was a gap in years and if the sequel had a much bigger budget. Here are some movies that I liked as much or more than the original: Star Trek: This is an obvious one. The original was pretty boring and the Wrath of Khan is generally considered to be one of the best Star Trek movies ever.Star Wars: I really did like the original and it was the start of one of the biggest movie franchises ever. However, there were parts of it that were really slow, like R2D2 rolling across the Tatoine landscape. Also, some of the the effects were a little shaky, even though they were amazing for the time. The Empire Strikes Back had a good storyline and is generally considered to be one of the best Star Wars movies. I really liked Return of the Jedi a lot too. It was actually the first one I saw in theaters.Terminator: The first Terminator film is a classic with classic lines, but the second one was a great story too and had much better effects, probably due to a bigger budget.Indiana Jones: I’m not a huge fan of Raiders and The Temple of Doom, but I really liked the Last Crusade.2010. Again, 2001 is a classic. However, it can be very slow in parts and there isn’t much dialog. I appreciate what it tried to do, but as a sci-fi fan, I thought 2010 was a much more engaging movie to watch.Back to the Future: This one is iffy for this list. I think Back to the Future may be one of the best movies ever made and I don’t think any of the sequels are better, but I liked the third one quite a bit, maybe almost as much as the first one.James Bond: There are many James Bond movies that I like more than the original. Of course I’m not sure you can consider this an original and sequels.Sisterhood of the Travelling Pants: I probably shouldn’t even admit that I watched these as a guy, but I think I liked the second one better.I’m sure there are many more that I can’t think of now, but you can see a theme. There were a number of successful movies that were pretty good or even classics that had a sequel made later with bigger budgets and better effects.

Following the Frozen fanatic fever from previous years, Frozen II came as a wonderfully soothing breath of fresh air.  It was a fresh air that stemmed from an unpredictable movie from Disney, in which they decided they wanted to make a brave remake. By abandoning the castle landscape, ditching the royalty subplots and substituting it all for a ambiguous ‘journey into the unknown’ Frozen II was able to move more freely and elegant than its predecessor had. Everything from Elsa’s distant voice, the spirits and the unknown history were all carried a mysteriously ethereal feel to them. I think that tapped into my love for such movies like Arrival and Annihilation. It felt very much like a playground of ideas all bursting with creativity, all merged into one film. I like to think they it more-or-less succeeded.  None of that however would be possible without the talent behind the screen. The 5 year gap between the original was evident in their animation developments, and the team assured the ethereal atmosphere this film carries. ‘Show Yourself’ still reigns supermen over all Frozen songs — that’s a certified fact. But it owes that, not only to Idina Menzel’s always-powerful vocals, but also to the sheer bravado of the animation during the song. It was truly spell-binding stuff. I believe while the sequel’s songs aren’t nearly as iconic or strong than the original, alone, they carry so much more weight when watched along with the animation ; It’s attest to their magnificent visual storytelling skills. In fact, everything here demonstrates a mastery of animation - particular probs to the wave scene. Not only was it a technical feat but it beautifully enhanced Elsa’s troubled state of mind. Oh, and Elsa looks like a complete badass riding the water horse. Can we all agree on that one?  And while the sub-par critical and audiences reception was mostly due to the ‘confusing’ narrative and the absence of a clear villain, I strongly believe that’s what set it apart. This film managed to take the path away from Disney’s increasingly clichè fairytale storylines and was able to craft something entirely new while standing its own ground — it was something more equivalent to an abstract animation. And while I can recognise where the criticism comes from, I believe this looser style of storytelling enabled the film to tackle themes of identity, change and sisterhood in a refreshingly nuanced and artistic way.  There was something palate cleansing about Frozen II. And in the age where an abundance of trash is spewing out from Disney, it’s all the more welcome. Certainly more welcome than Frozen that’s for sure. To all the people still obsessed with that film — just let it go.

Home Alone 2: Lost in New York is better than the original in every way: the comedy, 3rd act, setting and storySpider-Man 2 is the perfect mix of drama, romance, comedy and and action and a better story structureI have more problems with The Dark Knight than Batman Begins but its villain, story, themes and execution destroy Batman BeginsReturn Of The King is the perfect ending to the trilogy with incredible action, CGI, it’s intense, suspenseful and rarely slow unlike the first two moviesBack To The Future Part II, while being a bit messier, has a much more creative and imaginative plot and had everything that made the original outstandingTemple of Doom has much better pacing and much more violent, creative, imaginative and better action than Raiders, which is still amazingThor: Ragnarok is what the first 2 Thor movies should have been. It’s hilarious, has great action, villain and characters and settingChamber of Secrets has all the magic of the first Harry Potter movie but with better acting, visuals and a very well-executed and compelling mystery storyAvengers: Infinity War is the Avengers movie. It delivers with its action, comedy, villain, story and execution perfectlyThe Empire Strikes Back may be a bit slow in the 2nd act but it has better action and continues and expands the themes and story of the trilogy very wellRevenge of the Sith managed to avoid the problems of the first 2 prequels. It still suffers from those problems at times but not like the other two with outstanding visuals, action, acting and emotionToy Story 2, 3 and 4 have all the excitement and characters of the first Toy Story but better pacing, story structure and enjoyable throughoutKung Fu Panda 2 has all the great fight scenes and characters from the originals but has a much better villain, story and explores on more deeper and darker themesShrek 2 improves on everything that made the first great. It’s funnier, a more intriguing setting and story that expands on the universe and a better 3rd actRise of Skywalker is much better than Force Awakens. It has better action and its story is much more original than that movie and has great character interactions, visuals and a fun adventure movie (Don’t get triggered. Force Awakens had the most mediocre story ever)

Indeed I have, though there is something inherently inferior in the very idea of the sequel. It is also known for sequels to be more popular or widely accepted despite the fact they’re inferior to the original (the curious case of Terminator 2). My first one is at the same time the most controversial one for me, as I came to fully appreciate and even prefer the original over the years. But still, for most of my life/youth, I preferred Mad Max 2 aka The Road Warrior (1981) over both the original Mad Max (1979), and the last in the series - Beyond Thunderdome (1985) . In any case, it is a marvelously executed sequel and one of the prime examples of what sequel should be, if done at all. As it was unable to repeat the incredible shock and realism of the original, it opted for a more Sci-Fi approach, choosing to focus on what is to become the most widely recognisable trait of the franchise - a dreaded sense of permanent threat. And okay, the insane stunts/spectacular crashes.  Rocky IV (1985) is an iconic character receiving an injection of pure 80’s manliness, turning it into a proverbially simplistic, but unrepentantly macho, testosterone overloaded tsunami of badassery propelled forward by a hype inducing, adrenaline heavy score by Vince DiCola. Rocky IV OST alone has more iconic themes and songs than the entire 21st century so far. While not the best, nor necessarily superior to its slower paced, character study of an original, Rocky IV was the sequel I return most to, if nothing, for the coolness factor and its straightforward, unapologetic 80s-ness it wears with pride.  The Lord of The Rings franchise has never been quite my thing. I respect the elaborate-ness of its world, the excellent villains etc. but the hype around it is just as puzzling to me now as it was back then. However, the juggernaut of a movie franchise it was, it was unavoidable. Like eating at McDonald’s. But unlike McDonald’s - it was always a good experience, even if a bit too long. Of all those, the most memorable for me was the sequel - The Two Towers (2002). It didn’t seem to be as heavy on lore as the first one, it was darker and more action packed, or at least it was how I remember it. And the night battle sequence was pretty badass. The unstoppable suicide charge of a buffed up lunatic was pretty memorable.  I consider Tim Burton’s Batman to be the best portrayal of this particular superhero in film (though Michael Keaton is terribly miscast). Overrated Nolan films, while okay as far as film goes, have no particular flavour of a Batman film, just a generic action film dressed up as Batman (loose the terribly out of place costume/character and nothing would change), as ignorant or careless about Batman’s world or lore as Nolan himself. Having said that, the 1989 one, while amazing in many aspects never grew on me quite the same as the sequel. It might have been me preferring good casting choices in such films (and the original was too bad at that), but Batman Returns (1992) is what a Batman movie is supposed to be, and as close as one can/could get (apparently) to the beloved comic book character/animated series.  The last one is a bit different in tone and origin. The Japanese horror movie Ju On: The Grudge (2002) succeeded doing everything its (too) low budget predecessor(s) couldn’t achieve. It took the idea, the incredibly unsettling, mournful, eerie atmosphere and provided a more polished, more impactful version of the story. The sequel is easily the best one in an incredibly (and regrettably) long franchise,  and arguably one of the best horror movies in general.

There are five sequels in existence that I love beyond all others, that I would be willing to consider some of my all time favorite films. But, surprisingly, of those five films three of them I enjoy the first movie more. Two of those movies are Lord of the Rings films. My favorite of the trilogy is Fellowship, but I also love the other two and rewatch them every year. Few moments in cinema are more exciting than The Charge of the Rohirrim or more brilliant than when Gollum talks to himself.  The other one is my favorite sequel of all time, Before Midnight, which is more stressful than the entirety of the Safdie’s filmography combined. That’s not even mentioning the hilarious dialogue and huge amount of truth in the final scene, a scene that subtly shows the crazy fact of life that not everything needs to work to work out. Despite Midnight currently being my 7th favorite film of the decade, I like Before Sunrise more.  Also, before going into what my two choices for superior sequels are, it’s probably worth mentioning that I haven’t seen The Human Condition or Apu Trilogies and am not counting films that are part of narrativeless trilogies (Think Bergman’s Faith or Man With No Name).  The first is Alfonso Cuaron’s magnificent entry into the Harry Potter franchise: The Prisoner of Azkaban. Cuaron is, by a pretty wide margin, the finest artist to ever work with Harry Potter and his endless creativity is on full display in this one. Images are filled with meaning and beauty in a way few franchise films have ever matched.  Cuaron is a master of using simple motifs and images to create this meaning. Think of how the poster of Sirius Black is framed in this long take, constantly in the peripheral of the viewer as he is discussed. But he is also outside of Harry’s vision, representing our protagonists naïve view of the dangers that face him. But images aren’t the extent of his talents. Cuaron is really able to make the melodrama work in this film by controlling his actors. Radcliffe gives a more reserved performance in this film than in any other entry of the series and that works wonders for showing his desperation.  Cuaron makes sure it isn’t Harry Potter who is terribly in need of a father figure. That doesn’t work as well, because Harry Potter is the chosen one — a fictional character. Instead he turns Potter into a rather helpless, totally out of his league boy who needs a father, allowing the audience to relate to him. Azkaban is the only Harry Potter film that really allows the viewer to feel Potter’s vulnerability. With any of the other directors, something like Harry blowing up Aunt Marge would be treated like comic justice. In Azkaban, Cuaron shows how it brings Harry into a world of trouble that he just barely escapes from, albeit with consequences.  Cuaron allows the viewer to treat his ‘chosen one’ protagonist as undeniably fallible, which is why the film works so well. In films like A Little Princess, Y Tu Mama Tambien, and Solo Con Tu Parejas Cuaron had already shown he could make an all time great coming of age drama. The fact Prisoner of Azkaban was a sequel with wizards wasn’t about to stop him from being customarily brilliant.  But the next incredible follow up is from a director who is virtually the complete opposite of Cuaron. While Cuaron is soft and moving, Sam Raimi is in your face and constantly comedic. I am of course talking about Sam Raimi’s Spider-Man 2.  Raimi’s superpower is certainly keeping control of tone. The director weaves a web of horror, comedy, and action that all somehow keep a consistent aesthetic. It has some of the most perfectly compiled action ever, moments like the train fight stay constantly tense as while as regularly hilarious. The film is just so regularly funny. But, as all great directors should do, Raimi draws more comedy from his visuals than his script.  But it isn’t just a monumentally fun action romp. This is a film that, just like Azkaban, has the courage to treat its superpowered protagonist as vulnerable. Peter Parker is drawn away from the hero life in the film, it starts to weigh on him too much. The best scene in the film, hell my favorite scene in any comic book film, is after Peter throws away the suit. Most directors would cut to him wrestling with his situation, but instead Raimi throws in a visual joke. In a montage that looks straight out of a bad 70s SitCom, we see Parker confidently walking to the song “Raindrops Keep Falling on my Head” with a goofy grin on his face.  It shows the sacrifice of being a hero instead of heroic sacrifice. It makes the case that Parker’s life would be better if he didn’t have superpowers, a more mature argument than this silly early-2000s action film had any business exploring. Parker’s character arc, how he wrestles with his own ability, is what separates this film from its predecessor. It eschews the traditional comic book structure to tell a story of a person that is actually universal. We all have to wrestle with our talents and wonder if our ambition to accomplish dreams is worth it.  One thing makes this a very special superhero film; that separates it from every other comic book movie made. It is very much not about a guy in a suit who punches people.

Hell yes. Now don’t get me wrong, I loved Thor 1. Great movie in my opinion. But Thor Ragnarok was on a whole other fucking level. For starters, we got my favourite villain ever (cause Loki isn’t a villain, you can fight me on that). Hela was perfect. Great backstory, brilliant acting and a great costume too.  The overall theme of the movie was amazing too. There was a big contrast between The Dark World and Thor 1. Look at the titles for an instance.   Those have that sort of fancy, mythical sort of vibe. Then we have this…  Colourful, more scifi sort of style, which reflects the theme of the movie. Ragnarok was also a lot funnier, which always scores points for me. The others had some good points, the highlight probably being this scene:  But on the whole, Ragnarok was much funnier:    I always lose my shit at that scene. Always. It was also pretty amazing to see the character development for all of them, and finally see Loki treated as more of a protagonist than an antagonist. Plus, we got Valkyrie!  The only thing I didn’t like was the end credits scene. And knowing what it leads into…I bet you can guess why.

Question addressed: “Have you ever enjoyed a sequel more than the original movie? Why?” Several answers have already mentioned the Harve Bennett Star Trek movies. But in this case, I will say that I particularly enjoyed The Rescuers Down Under from 1990. A sequel to The Rescuers from 1977. I found The Rescuers to be dull, almost pointless and with a storyline that actually put me to sleep as a ten year old. In 1990, I met two dear friends who took me to dinner and to see the latest Disney film, The Rescuers Down Under. My entire moviegoing experience exceeded my expectations in many ways. Firstly, I saw this movie in a theater that'd been built to comply with the ADA, which had been signed less than a year previously. I adored the lopsided theater configuration that allowed optimal seating and access to the rear of the theater for prime viewing spots for anyone who was wheelchair bound. Then, before the movie came the short film. This was Mickey Mouse in The Prince And The Pauper, the first Mickey Mouse appearance in almost 20 years. After the short film, there was an intermission of about 10 minutes that played instrumental versions of Disney songs. The intermission card on screen was a picture of a Mickey Mouse hand from a Mickey Mouse clock on an image of a clock face. There was a countdown timer on the screen along with the musical interlude. Then when the timer reached 10 seconds, the Mickey Mouse hand ticked down the last ten seconds. It actually received cheers from the audience. Then came the feature presentation. This was the first Disney animated movie that used extensive digital processing for their landscape and wide shot movements, and you could see the enormity of the work the animators created when they showed off the point-of-view of the eagle flying over the Outback and landing on the cliff facade alongside the waterfall. It seems that this setting was chosen expressly to show off the amazing digitalized effects in Disney’s animation system. This movie had interesting characters, and many references and callbacks to the original 1977 movie. The story was interesting, the characters including the antagonist, Percival McLeach were well written and easy to identify with. The entire movie was a visual treat. The sequel to The Rescuers was, in short, much better and more engaging and enjoyable that the original The Rescuers.

There are plenty of movie sequels that were better than the original, and I will provide a few that MOST consider are better (but even then, there could be people who disagree with ALL my entrees, so I put multiple so hopefully everyone can at least agree with me on ONE). Remember, ALL OF THESE ARE MY OPINION SO PLEASE DON’T HARASS ME IN THE COMMENTS BY PUTTING YOUR OPINION AS IF IT AS A FACT (thank you):  Arguably the best Star Wars movie ever, The Empire Strikes Back is considered to be better than A New Hope on every level of the overall quality of the movie (and some consider it to be among the greatest films of all time), and I personally agree. Plus, it brought us one of the most iconic scenes in cinematic history: “No, I am your father” (I am not saying iconic scenes make a movie better, but they do help at times).  While The Dark Knight is said by many to be the best superhero film, there are many others who would argue that Spider-Man 2 is better. Either way, most consider this film to be better than Spider-Man due to its strong acting performances, incredible villain, and the developed romance between Peter and MJ. Additionally, it contained an iconic scene where Peter was stopping the train.  Paddington 2 has been considered by critics and audiences to be significantly better than the prequel, and I personally agree, since I liked the story, the introduction of the new characters, how Paddington was able to change a prison, and the ending was so satisfying that it almost made me tear up. Overall great film.  Widely considered to be the greatest superhero movie and one of the best movies of all time, The Dark Knight is a considerable upgrade from Batman Begins, an already-good film (in my opinion). From the phenomenal acting of Heath Ledger to the incredible story, this film was exceptional to me and many others.   Both of these films are considered by many to be upgrades from the original Toy Story, with Toy Story 2 featuring a new adventure and building up on previous characters while introducing new ones, and Toy Story 3 including a sad but satisfying ending to the trilogy (until Toy Story 4, but most consider it to not be in the same tier as the other three).  Another superhero movie revered as one of the greatest by many, Logan was incredible after witnessing its two meh (at best) films before it. The film contained a great story, good character development, and an incredibly sad death with a great ending to the trilogy making up for the two previous movies.  I’m not sure if this can be included because Deathly Hallows Part 1 isn’t really an “original”, but I will include it anyway. As I’ve said numerous times with the other films, most critics and audience members applaud this film more than Part 1, which was considered to just be setting up for the big finale, which was Part 2. This movie delivered good action, heartfelt scenes, and what most would consider a good ending to the saga. If I haven’t included other films, then it’s because these are just the ones that I feel many people would easily consider better than the original (though I probably missed others, such as Godfather Part II, Return of the King, etc., but I just tried to answer the question).

Yes, it’s Aliens. Ridley Scott brought “Alien” to life from an original script by Dan O’Bannon. [Thanks for the correction Justin!] Imagine an alien creature that seizes a fellow crewmember and the rest of the exploration crew might be contaminated/infected. Protocol requires quarantine to prevent contamination to others. But the life and death moral dilemma comes early: do we abandon humans in mortal danger when we might be able to save them OR do we play it safe by leaving them to die thus preserving our own lives? These COVID days, quarantine becomes all too real. In the movie, Ripley the ranking leader decides to follow protocol while Ash the ship’s scientist disobeys Ripley and lets them back in the ship. But Ash’s decision was selfish, for the sake of scientific experimentation, instead of altruistic, that is to save lives.  What the crew didn’t know was that alien species impregnates its prey before coming (birthed) out of the human cocoon. Here’s the famous kitchen scene.  This factoid is from IMDB. “For the chestburster sequence, Sir John Hurt stuck his head, shoulders and arms through a hole in the mess table, linking up with a mechanical torso that was packed with compressed air (to create the forceful exit of the alien) and lots of animal guts (which, according to Sigourney Weaver, caused the set to smell horribly). The rest of the cast were not told that real blood and guts were being used, so as to provoke genuine reactions of shock and disgust. Apparently, this worked so well that Yaphet Kotto went home in complete shock afterwards, locking himself in a room and refusing to talk to his wife for several hours.” Oh yeah, this species is virtually indestructible because it is huge, strong and bleeds acid. The rest of the movie is standard sci-fi stuff and the protagonist eventually defeats the alien. A plausible life and death moral dilemma accompanied by state of the art visual effects at the time, shocking original concept of chest-bursting birth, and dark foreboding throughout the movie. What can a sequel, lacking originality, have to offer? More chest-bursting? OK but we’ve seen it and we’re not as impressed anymore. Enter James Cameron’s vision for a sequel. This time, bring back the heroine Ripley back to investigate what happened to a space colony. Hell no because I barely survived that experience and it’s still haunting me in my dreams! Yeah but this time, you’ll be safe (reminds me (just now I confess) of the witches threefold guarantee of McBeth’s safety) because elite battle-tested Marines with cool gadgets will protect you!  Promises, promises. Here’s the shootout scene.  Then there’s another moral dilemma. Are decisions being made that value money over human safety? I think every day! The script is engaging, funny at times and tragic. The movie is epic and haunting.  Carrie Henn is perfectly cast as the sole survivor of this nightmare but Sigourney Weaver shines especially bright as the heroine Ripley.   Watch it if you haven’t. James Cameron’s “Aliens” is good enough to stand on its own without the original. I think it is better than the original.  Heck, watch both. There’s something awesome about each director’s vision. P.S. You can skip all the Alien sequels after “Aliens.” They are not worth your time.

Terminator 2 was clearly better than the first film. The first one was an achievement considering its modest budget and everything, but the sequel is perhaps one of the best action movies ever made. The Empire Strikes Back is also one of the best sequels of all time and a very strong candidate for the best Star Wars film of all time, however the original Star Wars had such an incredible impact on everything that it makes choosing between the two really difficult. When pressed I still choose ESB as my favourite before A New Hope. Aliens is also a frequently quoted excellent sequel, but the original was so different and so good at what it did, that I can’t say that I agree fully about Aliens being better. The original film was a space thriller/horror film. The sequel went clearly into action movie territory, although it was tense and claustrophobic, like the previous film. Finally, perhaps the toughest call of them all: Godfather Part II. The original film starred Marlon Brando in one of the most iconic roles of his remarkable career alongside an excellent cast and a young Pacino. The sequel drew parallels between the rise of father and son, namely Robert De Niro and Al Pacino. There was hardly anyone who failed to deliver in their respective roles and even Nino Rota somehow managed to double-down on the amazing score. I honestly find it almost impossible to choose between these films. I can’t blame anyone for choosing Part II, however the original has a slight edge for me over the sequel due to Brando alone.

One of the instances when a sequel stood out to me as being much better than the original was Batman Begins, and its sequel, The Dark Knight.  Batman Begins is a film I enjoy watching, and I think it’s great, but for me, it is a film that does everything well, but doesn’t really excel in any of the areas it tries to. Batman Begins has a very important story to tell, and it does so extremely well, but unlike the sequels that came after it, the best parts of it didn’t come from its action sequences, or memorable villains, it came from watching Bruce Wayne’s change in character from a young man desperate to avenge the murder of his parents, to a hero who doesn’t kill, and has an incredibly strong moral compass. One of my biggest gripes with Batman Begins is how it handles action set-pieces, they simply never impressed me, and the finale with Batman trying to stop Ra’s Al Ghul from destroying Gotham in his crusade to end crime, just left me underwhelmed. The train sequence almost bored me, and I never felt like the set-pieces matched the level of quality that the Character development had. The Dark Knight was different to Batman Begins in all of these ways, and it became probably the best superhero film, ever. Upon watching The Dark Knight, one thing immediately became apparent to me, and that was the film’s handling of Gotham City. In Batman Begins, Gotham was portrayed as a dirty, grimy and mysterious city, with the whole place looking unstable. The Dark Knight completely changed this, and Gotham became a much cleaner, sleeker city with buildings and roads that resemble that of a city like Chicago, or maybe even New York. This was a welcome change to me, as I was never a fan of Gotham in Batman Begins.     Probably the one thing that people most admire about The Dark Knight, is the villain. Heath Ledger’s Joker is to me, the best superhero villain ever committed to screen. It has yet to be beaten, or competed with. Heath brought a certain complexity to the role, not just being a laughing clown who’s only intent is to cause chaos, the Joker actually has a goal, and he achieves it! There are few villains who are able to intimidate with such ease as the Joker, and in The Dark Knight, there are multiple scenes where you can feel the tension in the room when the Joker speaks. Because he’s so unpredictable, you have no idea what he’ll do. I could speak volumes about how great Heath Ledger’s Joker is, but I’m confident you all know this by now. The final thing that The Dark Knight did better than Batman Begins, is the action set-pieces, and the increase in quality here is incredible. One of my favourite sequences involves the Joker driving a truck, and Batman giving chase. The sequence is it beautifully shot, with the camera capturing every crucial moment, with not a single frame falling flat in its delivery. Something that’s equally important is the score from Hans Zimmer, which has massively improved, elevating every scene it’s in, but it’s also recognised for its absence, with silence being used to great effect. The stakes in The Dark Knight are not higher than they were in Batman Begins. In-fact they are lower, but the better directing in this film means that even a finale with less lives at stake, holds more weight this time around, and pulls you in more. I also love The Dark Knight Rises, and I hold it to a similar degree to its predecessor, but the impact that The Dark Knight had on the genre as a whole, elevates it beyond anything that came before, or after.

Do you think a sequel can top an original? Who can show me an example? John Updike published “Rabbit, Run” in 1960, the story of Harry “Rabbit” Angstrom, who realises that life is a bit more prosaic and troublesome than his former highschool basketball star status had led him to believe. But Updike then went on to do something that I’m not sure has been done elsewhere. He revisited the character approximately every 10 years, publishing “Rabbit Redux”, “Rabbit Is Rich” and “Rabbit At Rest” in 1971, 1981 and 1990, respectively. Not only had the character aged 10 more years in each of those novels, but so too had Updike himself. His style had evolved, his attitudes to certain things had matured. It was a fascinating exercise.  Image credit poetry dispatch & other notes from the underground I liked “Rabbit, Run” but I have to admit I struggled a little with “Rabbit Redux”. I loved “Rabbit Is Rich” and “Rabbit At Rest”, in the closing chapter of which I shed real tears. The title left no room for surprise, as the novel moved towards its inevitable ending. The last two both won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction and Updike is one of only three writers who have won that award twice.* The Pulitzers were well deserved, in my humble opinion. Maybe it helped that I read all four novels in one compendium edition, over the course of a month or so, sometime in the early nineties. I utterly immersed myself in Rabbit’s life and to me, he is the most fully realised character in literature. Updike went on to include a novella “Rabbit Remembered”, in a book of short stories in 2001. I almost wish he hadn’t. Rabbit without Rabbit wasn’t the same and the previous novels, in my mind, were complete and a thing unto themselves. To get back to the question, I don’t think I would say the first sequel was better than the original, but the second and third sequels definitely were.  *Many people have won other Pulitzers (e.g. Drama, Journalism) more times.

Baahubali: The conclusion, cuz it slaps. Disclaimer: I'm not going to talk much about the first film. This answer is incredibly leaning towards the sequel.😘 So to all the uncultured Indians out there(can't say I'll find many), Baahubali is a film about a young ruffian named Shivudu who falls in love with a beautiful lady and ends up uncovering his war-ridden past filled with deceit, betrayal, splendour and sadness. This is the poster of the first film.  It was a good film and it became a blockbuster hit and the reason? The ending left people confused. Imagine a person who loves a man like a father and is ready to support him through everything and he's even willing to give his life to him. The father figure admits to that person's son that he killed said man. Why? The answer's given in the sequel. Shivudu learns about his past and raises an army to overthrow his uncle, Palvaldevan. This is the poster of the second film.  A movie cannot be more perfect. It's god's gift to earth. It's one of India's highest earning movies and it was so highly anticipated that I could see paintings of the movie on the walls of Subways, McDonald's, Saravana bhavan, Sangeetha and Barbeque nation. Just look at the characters:        The power. Ah. The sets.    The coronation scenes of the king:      The war:          The outfits:   My eyes were glued to the screen throughout the movie and I watched it in the theatres 3 times, 21 times on TV. The splendour, the acting, the songs, the war and the dialogues; I can't. I literally can't speak enough about it. It's one of the world's most powerful historical films and you can fight me on this. I'm so proud of the reflection of our history. India was the second richest country in the world some 2000 years back. What you're seeing is not at all exaggerated. Some kingdoms in the Northern and Southern regions were even 100 times richer and more luxurious than this. So I hope you liked it. Please check this film out. Also, upvote, cuz I like seeing em big numbers.

The Empire Strikes Back is my alltime favorite movie, so yes. I should note here, though, that Empire was the first Star Wars film I ever saw, back in 1986. So it’s not quite fair to say that I enjoyed the sequel more, since I didn’t see A New Hope until about eight years after the first time I saw Empire. I think The Godfather Part II is superior to the original film. These movies I did watch in chronological order. So I can definitely say I prefer the sequel. I enjoy Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade more than Raiders. Similar to Star Wars, I saw Temple of Doom and Last Crusade many years before I saw Raiders, so my opinion may be affected by that. I prefer Octopussy to the other Bond films. Ant-Man and the Wasp is better than the first Ant-Man. Logan is better than any of the other solo Wolverine movies. X2: X-Men United is better than X-Men, and Days of Future Past is also better than the first X-men film. Toy Story 2 is better than Toy Story. Batman Returns is better than Batman. Winter Soldier is better than The First Avenger. Evil Dead 2 is better than Evil Dead. Harry Potter 8 is my favorite Potter film. Silence of the Lambs is better than Manhunter. The Avengers is the best MCU movie. Return of the King is definitely better than Two Towers, and only slightly better than Fellowship — though I go back and forth between liking Fellowship and Return more. Thor 3 is better than the first two. I’m sure there are plenty more I haven’t yet mentioned.

Without mentioning the usual, already written choices; a sequel I found to be more enjoyable than the original is: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows  I really liked A Game of Shadows, maybe not a whole lot more than the first film (which is pretty good on its own right), but still a tad more. The second film improved on certain aspects that I thought the first film lacked. So why did I love the second one more? First off the villains! While I loved Mark Strong as Lord Blackwood, he wasn’t anything beyond a 1 dimensional villain. He didn’t feel as dangerous as Moriarty, which was portrayed excellently by Jared Harris. Moriarty in A Game of Shadows felt like the best version of the legendary villain. You know he’s just as smart as Sherlock, which makes their encounters rather more interesting both knowing each to be an equal yet opposite of each other.  I also really liked the addition of Sebastian Moran, which Arthur Shelby (AKA Paul Anderson) portrayed quite well, I found it was an interesting contrast to Watson.  Another big thing that I found more enjoyable than the first one was the action scenes. That forrest battle scene is probably the pinnacle of Guy Ritchie’s action style. The perfect combination between slow motion and fast pace action makes the scene really quite memorable and exciting.  Also, the A Game of Shadows added something that was very much missing from the first one and is also one of the most known aspects of Sherlock Holmes: Mycroft Holmes! While Stephen Fry may be a bit too comedic for it, he still did a memorable job and added a little bit of his own to the character.  The overall story (while I felt it a bit convoluted at times), I also felt was more intriguing and less predictable, which led to a very nail bitting climax in Switzerland. The story was always moving, even if at times it feels like it doesn’t, it all makes sense by the end.  So for me A Game of Shadows manage to keep the best aspects of the first one, namely Sherlock and Watson, while also adding quite a bit more that will hopefully make for a satisfying conclusion in 2021 if/when the third film is released.

Have I ever enjoyed a sequel more than the original movie? Why? . One of the best sequels to any film comes from the Rocky franchise series. “Rocky 4 by far”. But, I am a very big fan of dancing and I love dancing movies. If you are a big fan of dancing movies, then you will definitely love what I am going to mention. This film is one of my favorites in all dancing movies that come out of Hollywood. It is a franchise series that started in 2006 and the movie is called: Step Up. And, it has five parts to this great series. My favorite sequel to this film is from the 2012 film: Step Up Revolution. I love hardcore and freestyle street dancing and this particular film has it all. And, what is so cool about this film is that almost the whole movie was based and filmed in Miami, Florida. This is the 4th installment (sequel) to the Step Up franchise series. The way this movie was told was beyond sick if you are a dance fanatic. I have been a huge fan of dancing for however long to understand for the love of different dance movies. And, for sure; Step Up Revolution is again one of my favorite dance films in Hollywood. Step Up Revolution is by far way better than the 2006 original Step Up film.

I have always loved Pirates of the Caribbean 2 more than the first one. I felt like the first one had problems with the story like if the script was not finished when they started with shooting. The tone of the film changed for me a lot during last hour or so and I did not like that. I loved the second one (I still thing it is the best one from the series) because of great villain, lot of funny scenes, great action, it was not boring at all and I really cared for the characters. The ending was a great cliffhanger too. Third and fourth movies do not exist for me. The fifth was okay.

Most people seem to be using Follow-Ups as examples, not true sequels. If something is already part of a series, e.g., James Bond, Star Trek, Harry Potter, then the second movie made of that property is not a sequel. Sequels have many hurdles and being part of an existing series is a free pass over many of them. Aliens was a sequel to Alien. I don’t know if it’s better, but I’m satisfied when a true sequel is not decidedly worse. Terminator 2 (by the same director) was another very good sequel. So were Back to the Future parts II and III, imo. The Empire Strikes Back is regarded as a very good sequel. I’d also nominate Toy Story 3, but I don’t know if rules prohibit that if I don’t think Toy Story 2 was a very good sequel. Most actual sequels are terrible. I don’t know that any of the non-shameful ones I’ve named actually TOP the original. (Certainly The Empire Strikes Back does not come close to topping Star Wars, and all the gazillion people who think so are certifiably insane.)

Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan is a far better movie than Star Trek: The Motion Picture. Captain America: Winter Soldier is better than The First Avenger. Thor: Ragnarok is better than either of its predecessors. I think Ant-Man and the Wasp is better than the original Ant-Man. Those are just off the top of my head. Yeah, I’ve been watching too much Marvel lately. :) Oh! The Bourne Supremacy is better than The Bourne Identity.

Were there movies you’ve seen where you enjoyed the sequel more than the original? Yes, but they were all continuing stories from a big universe, not retreads or spinoffs that came about after the studio realized they had a cash cow. Star Wars: A New Hope < The Empire Strikes Back The Force Awakens < The Last Jedi* Thor < Thor: Ragnarok (OMG Thor suuuuuucked) Batman < Batman Returns Batman Begins < The Dark Knight Star Trek: The Motion Picture < Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country Star Trek (2009) < Star Trek Beyond* A lot of people cite “Spider-Man 2” and “The Two Towers” as sequels that surpassed the original. I think I like the originals best because I was awestruck at seeing those properties on the big screen for the first time. “X-Men” had a graceful touch and an ebb and flow of pace that the heavy-handed disaster-a-minute sequel “X2” lacked. *Angry fanboys will not be engaged in the comments. Go find a YouTube review if you feel the need to fight about this.

Following the colossal critical and commercial success of 2016’s Deadpool, a sequel was pretty much guaranteed. And it certainly didn't disappoint.  The film opens with Wade attempting to commit suicide by blowing himself up. Formerly an asset, his immortality has now become a burden—an inescapable prison, trapping him against his will. He doesn’t get the luxury of death that the rest of us do.  We then see the reason for his suicidal urges—Vanessa’s death. The scene is slow, quiet and uncomfortable, and the grief and anger Wade feels is almost tangible, suffocating us, captivating us.  The opening credits scene was beautifully well-crafted. Reminiscent of the Bond films of old, Celine Dion gave us a glorious, superbly sung sequence. And of course, what would an opening credits scene be without that snarky dash of humour sprinkled in?  I loved the original film, but to me the sequel was, and always will be, a superior viewing experience. Josh Brolin and Zazie Beetz were wonderful additions to the already fun ensemble of actors. I particularly liked the references to Brolin’s endeavours as Thanos, the Mad Titan. As with the first film, Wade Wilson couldn’t miss out on some much-loved 4th wall breaking, a lovely addition to an almost perfect film.  But I think one of the main reasons I like this film so much is because it reminded me of another movie I hold dearly—Logan. Both films show the protagonist struggling without their powers, and both films give the protagonist a character they care about and risk their life for—Laura in Logan, and Russell in Deadpool 2. But seriously, I don’t like the way Wade was throwing shade to Logan in the opening scene. I mean, come on! The guy’s dead and you still can’t give him a shred of respect? Not cool, Pooly.

Have you ever enjoyed a sequel more than the original movie? Why? Of course, like everyone else said: Star Trek: The Motion Picture is empirically worse in every meaningful respect than Wrath of Khan.Star Wars: ESB is just plain better than ANH featuring a better story told better, with performances are legitimately decent.I would argue that in addition: James Bond: Daniel Craig era, Skyfall was to me the best of the series by a significant margin—best pay off of many non-villain storylines and a wonderful send-off to a beloved character.James Bond: classic era, Goldfinger is easily the high-water mark of the Connery years, but Lazenby’s On Her Majesty’s Secret Service is probably my all-time favorite script, owing to its lowest level of deviation from the source material.

Yes. Spider Man 2. I was not a huge fan of superhero movies as a kid. But I am a Roger Ebert fan. I saw a YouTube clip of his SM2 review. He himself cared for few superhero movies, but opens his TV review with: “Spider Man 2…may be the best superhero movie I have ever seen.” Woah. Later, there was a “Best of 2004” episode. It was the 4th best movie. Why? Because Peter Parker is treated like a human, rather than a boring kid without the costume. It’s deep, effective, and unlike any other superhero movie. I agree with all of this. I have seen this 5 times in the last 10 month and love it more each time. In the Bible, Paul says “I consider all loss knowing Christ Jesus is my Lord.” (Philippians 3:8) I have a similar approach: I consider all superhero movies to be loss knowing how great Spider Man 2 is. I saw Spider Man Homecoming recently. I liked it, but it isn’t anywhere near SM2.  I suggest seeing this if you don’t think it should at least be called great.

“Have you ever enjoyed a sequel more than the original movie? Why?” Yes. I preferred Aliens to the original Alien. I felt more engaged with the marines. I liked the interplay between Sigourney Weaver as Ripley and Michael Biehn’s Hicks. They had some great on screen chemistry. I felt Bill Paxton did a great job as Hudson. And, who did not love to hate Paul Reiser as Burke? Even the young Carrie Henn had a fine presence. As a matter of fact, I think I will watch it again tonight. -Doug

Terminator 2 And Kung Fu Panda 2 With Terminator 2 they had a even more menacing villain and it was just simply a more interesting movie to watch. and effects that still stand up today. Not really much else to say but its a highly enjoyable experience. Kung Fu Panda 2 the highest grossing animated film solely directed by a female director. It was a good decision to make this film darker than its previous one and the villain was enjoyable to watch from start to finished my favourite character in the franchise. It balanced all of its jokes and its serious moments near perfectly apart from one instance.

One can perhaps build a case that Terminator 2 is a better movie than the original Terminator, but since I saw T2 first, I guess I am inclined to regard it as the main story and T1 as some kind of optional backstory or prequel. But actually they should not be compared; they are different flavors and each should be taken for what it is. T2 is a slick, fast-moving, well-crafted action movie with groundbreaking special effects (and even after a quarter of a century, they stand up incredibly well). T1 is in many ways an atmospheric horror movie (with tragic romance thrown in); the seemingly unstoppable “monster” just happens to be a futuristic android instead of some supernatural thing. Some of the effects are dated; it is quite obvious when a rubber doll replaces Arnold, and stop motion always looks like stop motion. Some will however say that the dated effects are just charming.

I think Ant Man and the Wasp takes the cake as the sequel that I enjoyed more than the original. Not getting into spoilers, it managed great comedy, great plot, a great villain, and a perfect balance of on-screen time between Ant Man and Wasp at the same time. Plus that end credits scene? Oooh baby. The first one was really good but did have some villain problems and not as much comedy, but that isn’t to say I didn’t really enjoy it still.

“Have you ever enjoyed a sequel more than the original movie?” Yes. John Wick: Chapter 2 “Why?” No dogs were killedMore of the secret assassin world and all of its customs were explored on a bigger scale.The infamous pencil kills were finally shown instead of just being told.In my opinion, this one had the better “I don’t give a fuck” revenge kill than the first one. See video below.

I’ll limit this to second films, but the following films are generally considered superior to the originals: Terminator 2: Judgement Day Aliens The Empire Strikes Back The Godfather Part II Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan Toy Story 2 Rambo: First Blood Part II Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle X2: X-Men United The Dark Knight Spider-Man 2 Captain America: The Winter Soldier Friday the 13th Part II Catching Fire Far From Home If I am to add my personal opinion, I think Alien, A New Hope, The Godfather, and The First Avenger were each SLIGHTLY better than the second films. I would also add Halloween II (1981), Halloween II (2009), Children of the Corn II, It: Chapter II, Nightmare on Elm Street 2 (though I still hated it and never watch any other sequels in the saga), Aliens vs Predator: Requiem, The Two Towers, American Pie 2, Bad Boys II, Rocky II, Back to the Future Part II, New Moon, Mamma Mia: Here We Go Again (it’s as much a “sequel” as Godfather II is) GI Joe: Retaliation, and Revenge of the Fallen. I also believe Jaws 2 is pretty much as good as the original (but the third and fourth films are terrible). And Caddyshack II gets undeservedly crapped on.

Predator 2, Rambo 2, 3, and 4, die hard 2 and 3, the mummy returns, for a few dollars more, the good, the bad, and the ugly, T2, the matrix 2 and 3, desperado, the last crusade, the temple of doom, once upon a time in Mexico, the devil’s rejects (uncut), 3 from hell (uncut), the dark knight, sin city 2, hellboy 2, John wick 2 and 3 (and 4), The Raid 2, Deadpool 2, AVP 2 (uncut), the expendables 2, Blade 2 and 3, transporter 2, crank 2, the two towers, the return of the king, the hobbit 3 (R Rated Version), Friday the 13th Part 4 and 9 (uncut), universal soldier 4 (uncut), avengers 3, shrek 2 and 3

Evil Dead 2, Dead by Dawn and Evil Dead, Army of Darkness. The characters are more fleshed out(lol, demon dead guys)in both of the sequels. Part of the success of these movies is the wacky cult following that they gained because of Sam Raimi’s total weirdness and Bruce Campbell becoming the perfect representation of a self-serving anti-hero. Pretty sure each subsequent film had a bigger budget as well. Side note: my kids used to play ‘happy family’ with an 18 inch Ash doll dressed as a baby in a stroller complete with chainsaw hand and sawed-off shotgun. Every so often I would hear , “This is my BOOMSTICK!” …still makes me smile.

Yes, The Mummy Returns (2001) was much better than The Mummy (1999). I enjoyed both movies, but the sequel hits on all cylinders and is a thoroughly enjoyable action/adventure movie. You just have to get past the timing of Rick and Eve’s son (he shouldn’t be that old already, given the dates proffered in the two movies), and some of the anachronisms, like keys in a car that should have had a push-button start, and the color of London Bridge at that time. Those sorts of things don’t bother me for this sequel; it’s just a delightful romp of a movie with characters you care about and villains you hate.

Sure. In my opinion: The Dark Knight > Batman Begins (within Nolan’s Batman trilogy);Ant Man and the Wasp > Ant Man (I thought that Ant Man was pretty awful, but I really enjoyed AM&W);Terminator 2 > Terminator;Lethal Weapon 2 > Lethal Weapon;Aliens > Alien;Evil Dead 2 > Evil Dead;Logan > The Wolverine;Before Sunset > Before Sunrise;Chronicles of Riddick > Pitch Black

Have you ever enjoyed a sequel more than the original movie? Why? Aliens was much better than Alien. 2010 was much better than 2001. Toy Story 2 was much better than Toy Story. Back to the Future 3 was a little better than 1 and much better than 2. Tremors 2 is as good as Tremors on repeat viewings. Aliens had more interesting characters and didn’t have as many stupidities. 2010 had more interesting characters and was not as boring on repeat viewings. Toy Story 2 was much more emotional and satisfying. Cowgirl went from being depressed to having a family again. Great stuff. I liked Back to the Future 3 because Doc Brown got a compatible companion, and what an attractive companion she was.

Star Wars. The Empire Strikes Back is better than A New Hope. Alien. Sorry, Aliens was better, man. Bill and Ted. Bogus Journey was a better film overall than Excellent Adventure. (Some people might come on here and tell you T2 was better than The Terminator. Those people are cracked.)

Everyone raves about Blade Runner and opinions on the sequel are divided. Personally I think the original is over rated and a bit of a snooze inducing mess. It looks fantastic and it established a lot of the tropes that sci-fi follows, but it’s not really that great. But the sequel is fantastic. It’s a brilliant piece of movie making that manages to be an outstanding film in it’s own right and actually explains some of the issues with the original. It’s not only a better movie than Blade Runner, it makes Blade Runner itself a bit better in retrospect.

The James Bond series got better with new episodes, I like Dr. No, but a few of the next ones were better, e.g. Goldfinger is great. Star Trek got better with sequels, Khan was great, The Voyage Home was great. Star Wars improved with Episode 5, but got weaker with Episode 6 and certainly with the prequels and the new ones.

As far as the Chris Pine Star Trek movies have gone both of which I like a lot, I would say I liked the sequel a bit more then the firstStar Trek Into Darkness . The story seemed more complex and the new crew members were a definite addition. Sadly Anton Yelchin has died and will be sorely missed if you want to see what I think was his last movie performance then look into.Thoroughbreds

I like Blade Runner 2049 much more than the original. I can’t even really say I like the original all that much. I never saw it growing up. Only watched it after reading the book in my early 20’s, and the movie pretty much ditches everything I thought was interesting about the book. At least the sequel was its own thing.

There used to be a saying, “Even-numbered Trek films don’t suck.” Implying that odd-numbered ones do. It’s true, though. Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan was far superior to Star Trek: The Motion Picture. I think most agree Star Treks 2, 4, & 6 are much better than 1, 3, & 5. After that, the saying fell out of favor as it wasn’t really accurate anymore with the Next Gen and reboot movies.

Examples of sequels that can be argued to have topped the original film include: From Russia with Love (1963), sequel to Dr. No (1962)Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back (1980), sequel to Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope (1977)The Road Warrior (1981), sequel to Mad Max (1979)Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982), sequel to Star Trek: The Motion Picture (1979)Terminator 2 (1991), sequel to The Terminator (1984)Toy Story 2 (1999), sequel to Toy Story (1995)X-Men 2 (2003), sequel to X-Men (2000)Spider-Man 2 (2004), sequel to Spider-Man (2002)The Dark Knight (2008), sequel to Batman Begins (2005)Captain America: The Winter Soldier (2014), sequel to Captain America: The First Avenger (2011)

The Mad Max franchise. The first Mad Max movie was basically a B-movie about car demolition in the Australian outback. The second, The Road Warrior, was a very good story and captured the zeitgeist of the 1980’s. The third movie, Beyond Thunder Dome, was not as good as the second, but was still okay and further expanded the universe. And the forth movie, Fury Road, was both a critical success and box office blockbuster.

A few: I thought Toy Story 2 and 3 were even better than Toy Story. I enjoyed Cyborg 2 much more than Cyborg, though that’s a low bar. Airplane 2 is even funnier than Airplane if, like me, you’re a science fiction fan who appreciates the sf references. The Bride of Frankenstein has even better performances and effects than Frankenstein. That’s all I can think of offhand. The Empire Strikes Back is arguably a better film than Star Wars, but I don’t think I enjoyed it any more than the original.

I could probably name a lot, but I’ll just stick with one… Aliens Alien was a great movie, introducing one of the world’s greatest villains and heroine. What I really loved about it was that they were pitted against something that was virtually unstoppable with the limited gear they had, yet one person managed to single-handedly defeat it after it had killed the rest of her crew. Truly a masterpiece. Aliens took the series to another level, bringing more action, story, and characters. It semi-sorta replicates the first movie, like I say, with more characters, more aliens, an alien queen, and numerous memorable quotes by the late Bill Paxton. Unlike the first, where the gang are trying to figure out how to kill the ALIEN, now the new gang are trying to figure out how to escape the ALIENS. Furthermore, I feel that the sequel has characters that you can admire more and practically root for e.g Hicks & Hudson, that is if you don’t already love Ripley.

I'm one of the few who thinks Godfather 2 is better than the first. Star Trek II — ST the motion pictureEmpire strikes back —- a new hopeSpiderman 2 — SpidermanX2 — XmenTerminator 2 — terminatorCaptain America the Winter soldier — CA the first avengerSilence of the lambs — manhunter

Raiders of the Lost Ark: third greatest film ever. Temple of Doom- somewhere in the top ten. Last Crusade: second greatest film ever. I don’t know why, but Last Crusade just seems more cleverly written and better directed than Temple of Doom, and slightly more so than Raiders. I went to see Last Crusade four times at the cinema; if I know it’s on the telly I cancel everything else if I can to watch it (even though I’ve got all three on DVD). Kingdom of the Crystal Skull was baaaaaaaaaad though. Oh God. We should round up every copy and burn them ceremonially. Greatest film ever is of course The Terminator. If you disagree, you are wrong. No arguments, you’re just wrong. Terminator 2 wasn’t bad, if I’d seen it before the first one I’d have thought it better than I do, but T3 was awful. We should burn that twice, just to make sure.

The 2nd Christopher Reeves’s Superman was much better than the first in my estimation and the best of the lot. Star Trek IV - The Original Series Movie was also the best of the lot. Both of these movies were more character driven than the usual violence and explosions type superhero/SF movie and that is why I liked them the most.

Ok here are some sequels that are better than the original : The Dark KnightThe Bourne SupremacySpider-Man 2Star Wars Episode V: The Empire Strikes BackThe Godfather Part IITerminator 2SkyfallCaptain America: The Winter SoldierThor: RagnarokDawn of the Planet of the ApesKill Bill Vol. 2

“Have you ever enjoyed a sequel more than the original movie? Why?” So far, there’s only one sequel I have watched that I consider superior to the first movie:  And that’s only because the first movie, although good, did not have much of the action and the spirit of the Original Series. The Wrath of Khan, although based on a very slim premisse, delivered everything the fans were waiting since the cancelation of TOS. And was, in fact, much, much better than the first movie. It is, in fact, considered by a lot of fans to be the best movie of the franchise (I consider it a close call between it and ST IV - The Voyage Home).

The odd/even rules for movies are a little interesting. Generally, if you have a good opening picture for a series, the producers try to recap too much on the glory of the first movie rather than take risks on a new plot element for the 2nd. In this case, the even movies generally suck. The odd ones force the producers to seek new and vibrant material and get a decent director. There is the opposite problem. What if you screwed up on the first movie but still want to keep the series going? Well, then (hopefully) the producers seek better writers, a better director and try to find something to make the 2nd movie better than the 1st. This is why even movies were generally pretty good for the Star Trek motion picture industry. http://www.cracked.com/article_15091_the-best-and-worst-star-trek-movies-all-time.html Why odd numbered Star Trek movies suck

I may get a bad rap for saying this, but I like the current Star Wars trilogy with Daisy Ridley and prefer it over the first trilogy by George Lucas. However, I was born in 2000 so it did not have as much of an impact on my generation compared to the current trilogy.
Yes, The Road Warrior was a better movie than Mad Max. Not that Mad Max was a bad movie…it was certainly good enough for a sequel. The sequel just happened to be better IMO.

The only one I can think of, right at this moment is;“Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade”  Even though I thought the first movie was excellent, I really liked this one better. The story was excellent and I loved Sean Connery as Indiana’s Father. Cheers.
GODFATHER II THE EMPIRE STRIKES BACK TERMINATOR II SUPERMAN II BRIDE OF FRANKENSTEIN STAR TREK II: THE WRATH OF KHAN

Yes! IMO, one of the best sequels ever is Spider-Man 2 (Tobey Maguire). It picks up the story perfectly after 2 years. Relationships have reasonably progressed, Peter Parker has adapted to his powers, and overall the plot and action are better. This happens a lot in superhero movies because the initial film spends way too much time on the origin story.

I enjoyed Steven Seagal's UNDER SIEGE 2: DARK TERRITORY considerably more than the original (which is good, for the record). It felt more fun than the first, I liked the scenario (and soundtrack) better, and I really loved Eric Bogosian and Marshall Bell as the villains. Plus, once it gets going, there's no let up. It just moves to the groove and I love it! 'nuff said!
A lot of them. Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back.  The Winter Soldier.  The Dark Knight.  Godfather part 2.  Spider-Man 2.  Shrek 2.  Attack of the Clones.

Godfather II over Godfather, by a slim margin. The way Coppolla wrapped the story in the second around the first, going back and forward in time, I felt was just brilliant. I’ve yet to see a better film.

I would add “Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan” to this list. A decidedly different film than “The Motion Picture.” The sequel excels in that it focuses on characterization, emotional depth and it has a compelling villain.

ADDAMS FAMILY VALUES. It was more creative and just more fun BATMAN RETURNS. Michelle Pfeiffer’s Catwoman was a great character and Pfeiffer’s performance was Oscar-worthy IMO. Those are the two I can think of right now.

Despicable Me 2 is the best of the whole franchise, and it's one I can watch over again and still enjoy. The music is good, the pace is fast, and the jokes strike the perfect balance of heart versus slapstick. The first Despicable Me is perhaps one of the lamest, boring movies I want burned from my brain. The third was mediocre and forgettable. But no. 2 is cinematic gold.

Yes, Deadpool 2. I think Deadpool two had better jokes and I like how they used Dopinder as more than just the taxi driver. I also just like gore and dark humor and there was a lot more sex jokes and decapitation in Deadpool 2.

Yes . Star Trek 2:. The Wrath Of Khan was awesome, and Star Trek 1:The Motion Picture was long, boring, repetitive, lame, slow, a rip off of “The Changeling" ( from ST-TOS) and full of mediocre acting.

Manon des Sources (1986) directed by Claude Berri. As a sequel to Jean de Florette this film isn’t necessarily better, it’s simply essential. While either film can stand on its own, the two together present an epic tale based on the simplest of premises. At their core the films are about farming and water. Sounds exciting right? Yet, so many things associated with the human condition are dramatized here. There’s toil and triumph, betrayal and revenge, downfall and redemption, intrigue and shocking revelation, it’s all here. Jean de Florette-  Manon des Sources-
Three examples off of the top of my head. Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan over Star Trek: The Motion Picture Jurassic Park III over Jurassic Park I Rocky III over Rocky I

The best Star Wars movie, easily for me, is The Empire Strikes Back. It, more than A New Hope, set the tone for what Star Wars is. I think the main difference is likely, that George Lucas had very little to do with the making of it.
The Godfather Part II, Aliens, T2, The Empire Strikes Back, Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan, should I continue?
I thought Spider-Man 2 (from the original trilogy, Toby Maguire as Spider-Man), was better than the original. Unfortunately, the 3rd one bombed.
Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan was way better than The Motion Picture. For one thing the special effects were much better and the plot line much better.

The Dark Knight, The Godfather Part II, and The Empire Strikes Back, Terminator 2 is my Holy Quadrinity of sequels. All four are prime examples on how to masterfully continue the story the previous movie while also outdoing it. All four of these movies successfully raise the stakes of the their respective series as a whole often leaving wanting more or with a ton of questions.
Aliens. I loved Alien but Aliens had more heart and a roster of excellent character actors.
I like Grease 2 more than i like Grease. Grease is over rated. Grease 2 is just better. No, i can’t explain why. :)
The Godfather Part II.
Aliens Terminator II Wrath of Khan Road Warrior Each one of these sequels was much more engaging than the original. Better acting, better script, better direction.
The Hunger Games: Mockingjay

Just off the top of my head, I would say The Dark Knight, The Bourne Supremacy, and Die Hard With a Vengeance were all superior to the original movies in their respective series.

I would argue that Shrek 2 is a better movie than the first Shrek (although that’s still great too). Also Toy Story 2.

Grease 2. Michelle Pfeiffer’s debut. Loved it! The name of her costar was very attractive but his name escapes me. I liked the chemistry better between them rather than John Travolta and Olivia Newton-John’s.

response.answer_text: Damien:omen2;a full separate movie;not copycaring the first success;the elevator scene with mescah Taylor,will have you laughing for weeks.
“Star Trek 2 - The Wrath of Khan” was a LOT better than “Star Trek - The Motion Picture”.
Dark Knight. Batman Begins was an engaging but otherwise forgettable origin story for Batman. Dark Knight gave us both Joker and 2-Face, without us ever thinking it was unrealistic.
Any Star Wars movie. That is any Star Wars movie following Episode IV: New Hope; the very first film that was released of the series.
Spiderman 2. Thor Ragnarok. Just a couple off the top of my head.
The Road Warrior, sequel to Mad Max.
Four words: “The Empire Strikes back”. ‘Nuff said.
